channel.title: Blog
channel.description: Resources and news in the areas of human rights, genocide, and world history

item.title: Gender & Genocide
item.description: Gender is an immensely complicated issue, and prevents complex questions when studying genocide. This short list, Bibliography of Gender & Genocide, again created with considerable help from Adam Jones, reflects the varied roles women have filled in the midst of genocide.

item.title: Political Science, International Relations & Genocide
item.description: Democide, mass murder, politicide, ethnic cleansing, genocide, gendercide - understanding these are an increasingly large part of navigating the world of international relations. Whether the solution is democracy, globalization, civic responsibility, the United Nations and other policing forces, or some combination of these and more, is all up for debate. I have put up another starter page, Bibliography of Political Science, International Relations & Genocide, (again with great thanks to the work by Adam Jones) dealing with just these topics.

item.title: Sociological & Anthropological Understandings of Genocide
item.description:
Sociology and anthropology focus on how societies and cultures function. This makes both disciplines essential to the study of mass-killing phenomena. Below is a link to a short, starter list of books, to be added to in the future. Please remember that I am always looking for recommendations of sites and books and other resources related to the material on this site.

Bibliography of Sociological & Anthropological Understandings of Genocide

item.title: Psychological Interpretations of Evil
item.description:
Understanding evil has been an endeavor for philosophers, theologians, humanists and social scientists for millennia. It is a fascinating and controversial area of study. Here I have put just a small, introductory list of texts on the topic, again largely thanks to Adam Jones, and I will be adding to it as time goes on.

Bibliography of Psychological Interpretations of Genocide & Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: The Former Yugoslavia
item.description:
Today I am simply putting up a small list of works dealing with the wars in the Balkans in the 1990s, wars which led to a vigorous attempt at ethnic cleansing and resulted in the deaths of approximately 100,000.

I recently read a book, a graphic novel, called Safe Area Gorazde. It is listed on the Bibliography of Ethnic Cleansing in the Former Yugoslavia page. Written from the perspective of its journalist author Joe Sacco, it did a very good job at making the experiences of Muslim individuals caught in the war in Eastern Bosnia vivid and personal to a reader who has never experienced anything like that. Sacco moved fluidly between the memories of the survivors and the present. Using the medium of the graphic novel, he made a difficult topic readable and understandable to a lay person.

item.title: Cambodia
item.description:
Cambodia is a place that I have wanted to travel to for a while. The photographs are beautiful, and those who have been there talk about the warmth of the people. There are ancient and beautiful temples and a lush, green landscape.

Today I am adding a short, ‘starter’, bibliography on the Cambodian genocide. The Cambodian Genocide Films page is already up and going, and I will add more to the Cambodian Genocide Bibliography page as I read and understand more.

The basic facts are these: Between 1975 and 1979, under the rule of Pol Pot and the Khmer Rouge, Cambodia lost nearly two million people from starvation, forced labor, and executions. Trials of perpetrators began only in 2006, thirty years later.

item.title: What’s Working
item.description:
I have been haphazard in my entries here. It is still a strange feeling to be journaling about a project in a public format. So, until I have developed more of an idea of what I want to say, I will just let you know what is working on the site.

Okay, here is a list of what on the site actually has content so far (I will update you with new additions through this blog as they are completed):
Homepage, “Our World”
Links (lists of what will be linked there)
Films (lists of what will be linked there)
Bibliographies (lists of what will be linked there)
Blog
About Me
Groups (podcasts and youtube have nothing, the rest have links but no descriptions)
Events(just five initial organizations)
Causes
Support
Bibliographies of the Rwandan Genocide (what will be linked there)
Bibliographies of the Holocaust (what will be linked there)
Links Regarding East Asia (links only, no descriptions yet)
Links Regarding India & South Asia (links only, no descriptions yet)
Bibliography of Politicide in the USSR
Bibliography of the Armenian Genocide
Bibliography of Personal Accounts of the Rwandan Genocide
Bibliography of Overviews of the Rwandan Genocide
Bibliography of Comparative and Introductions to Genocide
Bibliography of Genocide & Imperialism
Bibliography of Genocide & War
Bibliography of Genocide & Social Revolution
Bibliography of Genocide & Indigenous Peoples
Bibliography of Introductions to the Holocaust
Films Dealing with the Rwandan Genocide
Films Dealing with the French Revolution
Films Dealing with the Genocide in Darfur & Sudan
Films Dealing with Genocide in General
Films Dealing with the Genocide in East Timor
Films Dealing with Ethnic Cleansing in Kosovo, Bosnia & Herzegovina
Films Dealing with the Armenian Genocide
Films Dealing with the Cambodian Genocide
Films Dealing with the Cold War
Films Dealing with the U.S.S.R.
Films Dealing with World War II
Films Dealing with the Holocaust
Links Regarding Comparative & General Genocide
Links for Teacher Training & Organizations
Links Regarding the Rwandan Genocide
Links Regarding Human Rights & Women
Links Regarding Africa
Links for Websites by Teachers
Links for Maps & General Reference
Links by Geographic & Cultural Areas
Links for Curriculum & Lectures
Links for Outlines, Notes & Timelines

Obviously, most of these need additional sources and/or formatting. And, for some reason, the google search on the bottom of each page does not seem to be working, so I will try and figure out what is happening and fix it.

I have a ton of personal stuff to get done this week, like repairing my poor old corolla from its third break-in attempt this year, and trying to get some daytime sleep since my little girl is not so interested in doing that at night, but my goal is to get an introductory bibliography to the Holocaust done, to read, and to study for the GRE. I’m hoping that if I write it all here I will feel more accountable and stay on top of everything!

I want to thank Adam Jones, author of many books on genocide, for the invaluable lists of sources for further study and films on genocide war that he provides online and in his textbook, Genocide: A Comprehensive Introduction. These have become my starting place, and I am adding these sources to my lists first, to be built on later by myself and contributions you make.
